latest news.eng_title: Tech job seekers face hard times as industry resets
latest news.summary: The tech industry is currently undergoing a significant reset, with thousands of employees being laid off and hiring requirements being tightened. According to Layoffs.fyi, over 137,500 employees have been laid off from 438 tech companies since the start of the year. Meanwhile, postings for software development jobs have declined by over 30 percent since February 2020. Companies such as Alphabet, Amazon, Meta, and Microsoft have downsized, and employees who still have jobs are experiencing stagnant wage growth, with an average increase of just 0.95 percent in 2024 compared to last year. As Roger Lee, creator of Layoffs.fyi, said, 'The market isn't what it once was.' Companies are now focusing on revenue-generating products and services, and are looking for engineers with a broader skill set, including collaboration abilities and a working knowledge of the company's AI strategy. AI is one of the few areas experiencing growth, with individuals who have worked on large language models being offered salaries reaching $1 million a year.
latest news.title: Tech job seekers face hard times as industry resets

latest news.eng_title: Chip major Qualcomm to lay off hundreds of employees in US
latest news.summary: Qualcomm is reportedly laying off at least 226 employees in the US as part of its business diversification strategy. The layoffs, announced in a California Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) notice, will affect employees at 16 facilities across San Diego, including the company's headquarters. A Qualcomm spokesperson stated, 'As part of a normal course of business, we prioritize and align our investments, resources, and talent to ensure we are optimally positioned to take advantage of the unprecedented diversification opportunities in front of us.' This comes after the company laid off 1,258 workers last year and recorded $35.8 billion in annual revenue in 2023. Meanwhile, Cisco has also let go of thousands of employees, reducing its headcount by 7% or around 5,600 employees, following an earlier layoff in February. This year, more than 60,000 job cuts have happened across 254 companies, with companies like Tesla, Amazon, Google, TikTok, Snap, and Microsoft conducting layoffs.
latest news.title: Chip major Qualcomm to lay off hundreds of employees in US

latest news.eng_title: Tech Companies to be Cautious with Hiring Despite Interest Rate Cut
latest news.summary: Despite the interest rate cut by the US Federal Reserve, large tech companies are expected to be cautious when it comes to hiring. According to experts, the reduction, the first in four years, should theoretically boost hiring, but 'those scars are still quite fresh', explains Adam Stafford, CEO of recruitment platform Recruitics. Stafford believes that the rate cut will provide 'a small boost' to hiring, but warns that 'business leaders will be prudent before stepping on the accelerator'. Ryan Sutton, technology expert at recruitment firm Robert Half, agrees that the labor market could receive a push, but notes that companies will be 'cautiously optimistic'. 'I think this fall will be interesting', he reflects. Nick Bunker, Indeed Hiring Lab's director of economic research in North America, states that the rate cut reflects a renewed focus by the Federal Reserve on supporting the labor market, but does not expect it to have an immediate impact on hiring. 'A variety of factors are influencing hiring in large tech companies, and a single rate cut is unlikely to make a big difference', he explains in an email. Tech workers have faced a brutal streak of layoffs since 2023 and a cooling labor market after the pandemic hiring boom. However, experts in human resources assure that there are still promising areas for tech workers. Although tech layoffs have heavily affected employees in support areas such as HR and operations, Stafford notes that companies have invested in key tech talent this year, with jobs in data science, AI, and machine learning 'disappearing rapidly from the market'. And although hiring in the tech sector has been 'stable' and 'conservative' this year, Sutton comments that job seekers may see new opportunities soon, as those who expected rate cuts likely adjusted their budgets in August. 'It's probably now when we'll really start to see the first signs', he concludes.

latest news.eng_title: Massive layoffs for Cisco and IBM erase hundreds of Bay Area tech jobs
latest news.summary: Cisco Systems and IBM have announced massive layoffs in the Bay Area, resulting in the loss of over 1,000 tech jobs. According to official WARN notices, Cisco is cutting 842 jobs, including 563 in San Jose, 145 in Milpitas, and 134 in San Francisco. IBM is slashing 112 jobs, consisting of 58 positions in San Francisco and 54 at IBM Silicon Valley Lab in south San Jose's Coyote Valley. Advantest, a semiconductor testing firm, is chopping 88 jobs in Fremont. These layoffs are permanent and were scheduled to take effect in November. Since 2022, Cisco has cut 2,649 jobs in the Bay Area, while IBM has cut 165. This news comes after Cisco announced it would slash 7% of its workforce, potentially resulting in 5,900 job losses worldwide.
latest news.title: Massive layoffs for Cisco and IBM erase hundreds of Bay Area tech jobs

latest news.eng_title: Intesa Sanpaolo Announces Plan for Generational Replacement and Skills Development

Organization: FTSE Diversity and Inclusion Index – Top 100
Title: CEO

latest news.summary: Intesa Sanpaolo, led by CEO Carlo Messina, has announced a new plan for generational replacement and skills development, which will lead to the departure of over 3,000 employees through retirement. According to sources, the plan is not a layoff, but rather a retirement plan for employees who meet the necessary requirements to retire by 2028. The goal is to continue to support employees by requalifying various tasks and making them more tech-friendly. Intesa has already requalified 5,300 people with over 30 million hours of training provided by the company. The goal is to reach 8,000 requalifications by 2025. Employees leaving the company 'While negotiations with unions will begin in the coming weeks, several departures from the group have been announced by the end of the year. According to sources, 3,000 employees are expected to leave the company through retirement, with some potentially leaving as early as the next few months. The plan will be discussed in detail with unions between late September and early October 2024, with the first retirements expected by the end of the year. Intesa's recognition 'Intesa Sanpaolo can smile, as the company has been recognized as a healthy and inclusive workplace. According to the FTSE Diversity and Inclusion Index – Top 100, Intesa is the most inclusive workplace in Italy and seventh globally. The analysis, conducted on over 15,500 listed companies worldwide based on 24 parameters, has praised Intesa for its process of welcoming and valuing diversity in all its forms.'

news knowledge.eng_title: Tech Sector Sees Significant Layoffs in August 2024
news knowledge.summary: In August 2024, the tech sector saw a significant increase in layoffs, with over 27,000 employees losing their jobs. Major tech companies like Intel, IBM, and Cisco, as well as over 40 small startups, announced large-scale layoffs. This year, a total of 422 companies have laid off over 136,000 tech professionals. Intel announced a 15% workforce reduction, affecting 15,000 employees, as part of its broader strategy to cut $10 billion in costs by 2025. The company cited poor second-quarter results and a weak outlook. Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger said the company's revenue growth problem is due to high costs and low margins, despite having a 25-year dominance in the CPU chip market. Cisco Systems plans to cut around 7% of its global workforce, affecting around 6,000 employees, and focus on high-growth areas like AI and cybersecurity. This is Cisco's second major layoff this year. IBM is closing its research and development center in China, affecting over 1,000 employees, due to declining IT hardware demand and challenges in its expansion efforts in China. GoPro plans to cut around 15% of its workforce, affecting around 140 employees, as part of its restructuring strategy, expected to be completed by the end of 2024. Apple has laid off around 100 employees from its services division, affecting teams related to Apple Books and Apple Bookstore. This is part of Apple's AI-focused strategy, which has reduced the importance of Apple Books. Dell Technologies has restructured its sales teams and started a new AI-dedicated team. The company aims to increase its efficiency by simplifying its management structure and reassigning investments. This restructuring has affected 12,500 employees, around 10% of its global workforce. ShareChat, a social media firm based in Bengaluru, has cut around 5% of its workforce, affecting around 30-40 employees, after its bi-annual performance assessment. In 2023, there was a 15% increase in layoffs in the IT sector compared to the previous year. According to Layoffs.fyi, over 1,150 tech companies laid off over 260,000 employees in 2023. Amazon laid off around 16,000 employees, while Microsoft laid off 10,000 employees. Meta (Facebook's parent company) laid off over 10,000 employees, and SAP laid off 8,000 employees. In July 2024, 34 tech companies laid off over 8,000 employees, bringing the total number of layoffs this year to 124,517 across 384 companies.

news knowledge.eng_title: The US companies in the tech sector with the largest mass layoffs since 2020
news knowledge.summary: The tech industry experienced significant job instability following the COVID-19 pandemic, with major companies like Amazon, Meta, and Apple initiating large-scale layoffs. Google's January 2023 layoff of 12,000 employees was the largest single layoff event in the tech sector since 2020. In 2023, nearly 2,000 tech companies laid off over 260,000 employees, and the trend continued into 2024. Despite these layoffs, the stocks of Google, Meta, and Microsoft have risen significantly, with Microsoft reaching a valuation of $3 trillion earlier this year. According to Jeff Shulman, a professor at the University of Washington's Foster School of Business, 'there is a herding effect in tech,' where layoffs seem to help stock prices, leading companies to continue laying off employees. The low unionization rate in the tech industry, at 1% in 2022, further reduces workers' bargaining power.
